intro: Nepeta pabotii, commonly known as the Persian catmint, is a perennial herb native to the mountains of Central Asia. It belongs to the mint family, Lamiaceae, and is characterized by its aromatic, fuzzy leaves and spikes of blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its foliage is often used in traditional medicine, and it attracts pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
